p: Autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT) is a standard of care for eligible patients with newly diagnosed MM (NDMM) [ 3– 5]. Despite improvements in treatment, ASCT is not curative for most patients, with more than half of patients relapsing within 2 to 3 years after ASCT if they did not receive post-ASCT treatment [ 6– 10]. Thus, a key treatment goal for transplant-eligible patients with NDMM is to extend post-ASCT remission. Results of analyses examining survival outcomes and tolerability associated with interferon, corticosteroid, and thalidomide maintenance therapy have been inconsistent [ 11– 13]. Bortezomib maintenance has also been tested, with increased progression-free survival (PFS) noted [ 14, 15].
